conclusion: Trying to understand the problem involving a mass spectrometer with plates and fields.

Two metal plates, M and N, with a voltage U between them; plate Q is the recording plate; interface P divides region between N and Q into two parts: region I and region II, each with width d; plates are parallel; holes a and b in plates M and N are directly opposed.
Particle with mass m and charge +q starts from hole a and is accelerated by the electric field between plates M and N.
Electric field between M and N should be uniform, directed from N to M if U is positive.
Region II has an electric field along the positive x-axis.
Coordinate system: z-axis through holes a and b, positive direction to the right; x-axis parallel to plate Q, points horizontally inward; y-axis is vertically upward.

Particle starts at hole a, moves to hole b, enters region I with a magnetic field along the positive x-axis, passes through point c on plane P, enters region II with an electric field along the positive x-axis, and hits plate Q.
Goal is to find the radius R of the circular path in the magnetic field.
Electric field E1 between M and N is given by E1 = U / d_MN.
Distance from M to N is d, from N to P is d, and from P to Q is d.
In the region between M and N, there's an electric field E1 = U / d.
Particle is accelerated from a to b by the electric field.
Using conservation of energy: q * U = (1/2) m v_b^2, so v_b = sqrt(2 q U / m).
In region I, the particle moves in a circular path due to the magnetic force: q v_b B = m v_b^2 / R.
Radius R = m v_b / (q B) = sqrt(2 m U / q) / B.
Checking units: R = sqrt(2 m U / q) / B.
